item.title: Unified Mass Imaging Maps the Lipidome of Vertebrate Development
Spotiflow: accurate and efficient spot detection for fluorescence microscopy with deep stereographic flow regression
uMAIA published in Nature Methods
item.description:
We are excited to announce the publication of our work on uMAIA (unified Mass Imaging Analyzer) in Nature Methods.

uMAIA is an analytical framework for the joint analysis of large mass spectrometry imaging datasets. It enables the construction of multidimensional metabolomic atlases by extracting, aligning, and normalizing data into coherent, accurate maps. We applied this framework to study developmental lipidomics, creating detailed 4D lipid maps across embryonic stages.

This work represents a significant step forward in our understanding of how lipid diversity contributes to brain development and cellular identity.

Find the code at GitHub.

item.title: Spotiflow published in Nature Methods
item.description:
We are pleased to announce the publication of Spotiflow in Nature Methods.

Spotiflow is a deep learning method for subpixel-accurate spot detection in fluorescence microscopy images. The method formulates spot detection as a multiscale heatmap and stereographic flow regression problem, achieving state-of-the-art performance on diverse datasets while being robust to different noise conditions.

Key features include: - Subpixel-accurate 2D and 3D spot detection - Optimized for spatial transcriptomics workflows - Robust to low signal-to-noise ratio images - Available as Python library and napari plugin

This is a collaborative work with the Weigert Lab. Find the code at GitHub.

item.title: Congratulations Dr. Halima Hannah Schede!
item.description:
We are delighted to announce that Halima Hannah Schede has successfully defended her PhD thesis!

Halima joined as a PhD student in 2020 and completed her thesis jointly supervised with Prof. D’Angelo. Her research focused on computational approaches for spatialomics data: construction, integration, and analysis of biomolecular atlases. She developed Tomographer and made key contributions to the Lipid Brain Atlas project.

Halima has accepted a position as Lead Data Scientist at Implexis Ltd in London. Congratulations and best wishes for your future career!

item.title: uMAIA
item.description:

Key features: - Joint analysis of large MSI datasets - Spatial lipidomics clustering and imputation - Differential analysis tools - 4D lipid mapping across developmental stages

item.title: Highly Cited Researcher 2024
item.description:
We are honored to announce that Gioele La Manno has been recognized as a Highly Cited Researcher for 2024 by Clarivate Analytics.

For the second consecutive year, this recognition acknowledges the significant influence and impact of our research in single-cell genomics, RNA velocity methods, and computational biology for understanding developmental processes.

Thank you to all our collaborators and the broader research community for their support and engagement with our work.

item.title: Statistical inference with a manifold-constrained RNA velocity model uncovers cell cycle speed modulations
VeloCycle
item.description:
VeloCycle is a Bayesian model of RNA velocity that couples velocity field and manifold estimation in a unified framework, enabling formal statistical testing of gene expression dynamics. It fits an inferentially coherent model directly on raw data, eliminating heuristics that dominate current scRNA analyses.

Key features: - Formal statistical testing of dynamics - End-to-end Bayesian inference - Cell cycle speed quantification - Manifold-constrained velocity estimation

Find the GitHub repo here

item.title: VeloCycle published in Nature Methods
item.description:
We are excited to announce the publication of VeloCycle in Nature Methods.

VeloCycle is a Bayesian model of RNA velocity that couples velocity field and manifold estimation in a unified framework, enabling formal statistical testing of gene expression dynamics. It fits an inferentially coherent model directly on raw data, eliminating heuristics that dominate current scRNA analyses.

Key features include: - Formal statistical testing of dynamics - End-to-end Bayesian inference - Cell cycle speed quantification - Manifold-constrained velocity estimation

This work represents a major advance in making RNA velocity analysis statistically rigorous and interpretable. Find the code at GitHub.

item.title: Congratulations Dr. Alex Lederer!
item.description:
We are thrilled to celebrate Alex Lederer’s successful PhD defense!

Alex joined the lab as a PhD student in the Computational and Quantitative Biology program (EDCB) in 2019. His research focused on deciphering the nature of cell state transitions in single cells using quantitative modeling of temporal dynamics. His work contributed to major advances in RNA velocity methods, including developments in VeloCycle.

Alex has now moved on to become a Senior Data Scientist at CHUV. We wish him all the best in his new role!
